column1: #Text=The resulting solution was transferred to a flat ceramic dish, dried in a forced air oven at 120.degree.
#Text=(initially in 4%O.sub.2 /96%N.sub.2 for 6 hours followed by air at 600.degree.
#Text=Pt and Rh were then added at a loading of 0.8 wt. % (Pt/Rh=5), the composition re-calcined at 600.degree.
#Text=C. in air and finally aged at 1140.degree.
#Text=X-Ray diffraction (XRD) analysis showed the presence of two phases: Zr-doped CeO.sub.2 and Ce-doped ZrO.sub.2, as shown in FIG. 9.

#Text=The procedure of Example 8 was repeated, but with the inclusion of La to give a mole ratio of Ce:Zr:La=5.33:4.41:1. 280 grams of Ce nitrate (20 wt. % Ce) solution, 204 grams of Zr nitrate (14.8 wt. % Zr) solution and 43.4 grams of La nitrate (24 wt. % La) solution were added to 300 grams of deionized water.
#Text=To this solution were added 301 grams of d-sorbitol.
#Text=The resultant solution was dried, calcined, and aged as described in Example 8.
#Text=The X-Ray diffraction (XRD) analysis now shows only the presence of one phase after aging, i.e., shifted CeO.sub.2 phases, as shown in FIG. 14.
#Text=No phases associated with Zr or La are detected, thus showing that the La and Zr have doped the CeO.sub.2.
#Text=Examples 10 and 11 show that these same effects are observed when alumina is included and the mixed-metal oxide is supported on the alumina.
